review_blob: 12oz bottle.  So - its an imperial brown ale aged in bourbon barrels...this has a very strong nose, not really masking the 9%.  nonetheless, it smells like toffee, pure vanilla bean, and i can even pick up some chocolate and almond hints.  The taste is solid.  toasty oak, smuckers caramel syrup, and whaddaya know - i can taste some bourbon notes!.  the finish is lingering for quite a while.  this is a solid beer, and im now looking forward to the other 3 releases.  Built like a brick shit house.  hehe

aromas of fresh strawberries.  subtle syrupy sweetness, but more juicy than anything else.  also - i get some walnut.  taste is split between a fruity beer, and a brown ale, which is a bit perplexing.  slightly off-putting on the palate.  strong malty brew, but rasberries and dry roasted nuts dont seem like a great combination.  great beer, but not my style.

25 oz. Bottle.  (Dont get me wrong, I appreciate a good complex home/micro/craft-brew...) 
POW!  This ninja ipa bred with Alis right jab laid me out like Joe Frazier!  the taste reminds me of squeezing the hops of their juices pulled fresh outta the keg.  These hops are earthy (like a hippie un-doused in patchouli stench), tangy, and super grapefruit and lemon rind-y.  Although, the aromas are quite flowery and have an almost dainty caress (entirely misleading).  I may not be high, but definitely hop-high after this monster.  the finish is all forest floor, but i cant stop drinking it.  This is one powerful brew.  Definitely overt.  Its like SN threw on a Dogfish mask and robbed the hop bank.  But then again, extreme brews are a nice idea, too bad these I2pas, I3pas, etc. are just becoming the hoppy version of everclear.  I have an idea - lets dump as many hops as we can think of and just add enough malt to placate those who may enjoy an almost-tasty beer.   SN just hopped on the bandwagon (hehe), way to be like everybody else.  FAIL.
taste is mildly hoppy with a growing smoky finish.  clean and silky on the palate.  good lacing.  strong coffee finish, but still very smooth and inviting.  rock on.
beer_name: Terrapin Side Project Captn Krunkles Black IPA

review_blob: 2009 Vintage.  fizzy off-white head, quickly dissipating.  dark amber hue.  rather light for a bwine. aromas strong with caramel, belgian-esque yeast, malted winter wheat, and unripened dark pitted fruit.  this is truly one of the most unique noses ive found.  taste is lighter than most bwines, but incredibly delicious.  not nearly as strong of a sweetness, but more on the smoothness side.  dried apricots, lite maple syrup, and some near-doppelbock flavors arising on the back end, followed by a noticable yeastiness.  finishes clean, malty, fruity, and with a medium body. i think this is the perfect beer for near-spring in TN.  right beer@the right time.  I recommend this highly. ...and to think that i picked this up purely on a whim @Binnys on the South Loop...
beer_name: Two Brothers Bare Tree Weiss Wine (2002 and later)

review_blob: bottle. aromas of chocoalte marshmallows, coffee, and vanilla.  taste follows, but with additions of chocolate malts, nutmeg, and burnt coffee.  on the palate it is rich and creamy, followed by a smooth finish characteristic of a fine porter.  this is spot on, and there is no question this is rated as high as it is.  killer!

In short - superb ale.  there is little more that i can add that hasnt already been said before me.  IMO, spot on for the style; furthermore, it exceeds a few examples of true Belgian stouts.  crazy to think that Maine is that damn good, eh?

Bangin outta the bottle - though, thout it could be a barleywine at first; the nose is a touch misleading.  nonetheless - outstanding beverage!  the taste is def rich in chocolate, but also has a very silky texture, which really adds to the inviting nature of the beer.  the pepper is a touch subdued, but it wasnt the first beer on the menu either.  paired up with some chimay grand reserve cheese pretty well.
beer_name: Lagunitas Cruising with Ruben and The Jets

review_blob: this beer gets straight to the point:  if you want to get plowed, drink this.  Ill compare it to gin.  If you want a bad tasting, rank smelling beer - this is for you.  Ive told my friends that if you want king cobra to get you fucked up (without having to pound 40 oz of liquid, drink this.  its rediculous.  its an abomination that this is grouped with the craft beers in middle TN.  My sadness is growing beyond me.  If you want to get drunk quick, pound a few; if you want a flavorfully crafted ale - you will be disappointed.  try New Belgium or the Brooklyn Locals.

Immense.  This is epic.  the name sums up the appearance.  almost no head retention.  initial aromas are distinctly honey, vanilla, and an islay scotch.  holey hell (LOL).  This needs food.  The peaty smoke influenced by salty seafoam shines through the intense coffee and nutty chocolate flavors.  This is simply intense.  slightly bitter finish, i cant type enough about this ale.  im glad i tried it, but its almost too over-the-top.  This is definitely a specialty for the beer geek, not for the faint of heart! It definitely makes up for the lackluster Infinium I consumed yesterday.  Rock on Mikkeller!
beer_name: Mikkeller Black Hole Barrel Aged Edition Peat Whiskey

review_blob:
Appearance - dark straw/dull amber hue with prosecco-like bubbles, dissipating quickly.  
Aroma - clover honey, toffee, apricot flavored bubble gum, and fluffy bananas. smells like a crafty trippel.
Flavor - yikes!  thats a little sweeter than anticipated; and that carbonation cuts like a knife. That is an intense candy-esque flavored beer.  Strong honey and clove followed by a zesty carbonation; zing.  I can get a little vanilla bean on the back end.
Finish - candied bananas and heat from alcohol.

Comments - great <$12 beer.  yes, its a limited run and an interesting concept, but it falls into the "good" category.  When I pay for a limited release, I want superior flavor.  High marks for complexity on the front end; but low marks for the integration of those flavors into the overall experience.  Typical Sam Adams.
deep rich brown hue.  buttery hazelnut and roasted milk chocolate aroma.  dirty, grainy, and a mild bacon & mocha taste, grassy hops.  roasty, toasty velvet palate.  highly impressive for the style.

Bomber pours orange/amer/bronze with a creamy white head - with thick lacing.  aromas are thick - good bud, sharp pine, subtle floral, and strong acidic citrus.  taste is solid - orange upside down cake, grapefruit and lymon smoothie (topped with pine needles), with a well masked 6.5%.  finish is lengthy and pleasingly bitter, with a subtle sweetness hidden underneath.  Overall, an extremely pleasing beer with resin-like residuals.  This is killer for a saturday afternoon session beer.

a black hole with a thick brown head.  The aroma is definitely complex.  dark roasted coffee, mounds of bittersweet chocolate - like real cacao, vanilla bean, hints of toffee and hazelnut.  This stout doesnt mess around.  On the palate, in addition to the mirrored aromas, is a mouthfeel of velvet and a killer warming sensation.  The chocolate is all over the taste, but so is a growing nutty flavor, as the beer warms.  This is one tasty brew.  I cant wait to get a few more.  I wanna pair this up with some chocolate cheesecake.

The head is less than expected.  looks to be a golden honey hue. dry, yeasty aroma of lemon peel and subtle tangerine, hints of sweet basil and starfruit. tastes more malty than a typical Belgian Golden, with subdues citrus but strong honey on a fairly short finish.  Though very refreshing and a great accompaniment to aged parm, not a fantasic beer.  Has its strong points.

mahogany in hue, similar to that of a doppelbock, but a thicker head.  roasted molases, subtle salinity, subtle yeast, and maple syrup nail the aromas.  lighter than expected on the nose.  wow what a body!  contrary to the nose, the flavor still hits the bwine style, just in a lighter manner.  more dominant madeira notes hit the palate, almost mirroring a simple tawny port with excess carbonation.  toffee, heat, and maple sap shine through the fullest.  I still stand by the aroma leading to a lighter style (less robust than most bwines).  Nonetheless, quite a tasty pour.  *Note* - As the brew warms, the mellowness is achieved, and the anise begins to dominate.  cellar temp may be a bit too chilly here.

mahogany in appearance, frothy head, typical of the belgians.  nose is at first whiff - pure pumpkin spice, follows with nutmeg and a creamy curry powder.  interesting for sure - worth a good nosing.    Taste makes me think of a subtly yeasty, mildly hoppy, spices-dumped-into-the-brew attempt.  Lucklily, this is not overkill, simply an original winter warmer.  subtle allspice, with tons of spices and holiday scents rightfully reminiscent of a BSA/Spice ale.  This needs a dessert, i.e. pumpkin pie.  or something similar.  Yay! - unification of food and beer is present.  rock on, chouffe!

aroma - all yeast and crystal malts, no hops present.  it smells crisp, like lemon juice with subtle grapefruit and undertones of banana peel.  appearance?  light golden straw crossed with dehydrated urine, hehehe.   Taste - mellow, crisp, juicy citrus, faint tropical fruit, minimal salty finish.  great with sushi and sashimi.  lighter fare paired on purpose.  tasty from the can.  slight spice from carbonation, not from flavor.  Yella Pils needs food.
beer_name: Oskar Blues Mamas Little Yella Pils
Moylans Hopsickle Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: looks like a stout...smells like a belgian stout.  definitely a belgain stout from the yeasty aroma.  the name fits the brew.  somehow its semi-belgian, chocolate-y, and stout-ish.  it hasnt quite integrated all of the aspects of the name, yet it has made a valiant attempt as such.  its funny that all the aspects shine through of each of the three styles, yet nothing really integrates too gracefully.  as a belgian ale, its pretty good, and definitely unique.  as a stout...well, ive seen worse, but ive also seen far better.  the malts show themselves as the ale warms, yet it still feels as though it is lacking the stout mentality.  its like the brew is a bit of a conundrum, in that - it doesnt know what it wants to be.  great idea, ommegang (or duvel).  but the execution could have fared to more advantageous results.

pours with a tremendous amount of lacing, and thick at that.  the aromas are amazing with light peach, heavy orange/citrus, and copious amounts of alpha and beta hoppage.  the taste is intense - hops through the wazoo, piney, citrus-filled, and delightful orange peel.  its soft on the palate, but pleasantly bitter yest smooth.  kick ass - thanks mike!

12 oz bottle.  it looks like a black hole with a cappuccino head.  All light is absorbed.  raisins, chocolate, roasted malts, and rich, thick molasses dominate the aromas while chilled coffee bean and frappacino lay sedated underneath.  the dark cacao explodes on top of all that accented by rich, chocolate marshmallows.  intense, to say the least.  rich, milk chocolate and dark creme de caco is enriched by the raisiny alcohol on the palate.  one sip, two sips, stout sip, perfect sips.  though the alcohol did not set off any alarms on the aroma, it definitely cuts through the palate.  velvet-like carbonated silk is how i could describe the ale waltzing all over my palate.  the palate mirrors the aromas, but accentuates the strong espresso bean flavor, dipped in hearty dark chocolate.  not only does this ale exude the  characteristics of the stronger beers, but also that which embodies the definition of an imperial stout.  while the heat provides an aspect of allspice and black pepper, it is still always a pleasure to taste near-perfection.

first of all, it should be noted that i judge on a curve, and that sam adams needs a lot to get a good rating on a beer, as with most beer dorks.  

aromas of strong dark cacao and semi-sweet baking chocolate, followed by an underlying layer of robusto coffee smores fresh from a campfire.  perhaps this isnt the best aroma for an IS, but it certainly brings back memories of childhood.  this pitch black brew appears to have a rich, creamy taste based on the "midnight lace...and creamy espresso..." head.  the aromas also yield a pleasant toastiness and strong toffee and molasses undertone.  on the palate, this chewy chocolate-ey stout  shows the versatility of a solid stout.  roasted malts reveal the deep character, with layers of dark chocolate, brown sugar, black coffee (perhaps with a hint of tia maria shot in there), and just a note of alcohol.  sams stout is almost a great replica of youngs double chocolate with increased noticed alcohol on the palate.  its a defnitely a tasty brew, and one that will definitely remind you that theres no better time for a stout than in the tail of winter.  congrats, sam adams (and the BBC), you have made a quality product.  this is a first, aside from the extreme series.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: hazy goldeen hue.  allspice and earthy hops on the nose, followed by hints of coriander and mild sweet citrus.  the taste yields a mirrored palate of the aroma, with a grassy barnyard component.  the finish is well-rounded, smooth, but slightly high in carbonation.  the yeast is definitely prominent in this young ale.  should develop nicely over the next few years.
beer_name: Stone 20th Anniversary Encore Series: 08.08.08 Vertical Epic Ale

review_blob: Its hard to believe this brew is made by hte same people that make ohanlans.  no disrespect, but this ale is far superior to what i have tasted previously from them.  this is truly a barley wine, and not just an ale styled after it.  no carbonation, no head - its like a mead, but dark, fruity, sweet, and oaky.  the nose resembles botrytis in a way - pushing the idea of the overripe apricots and heavy molasses, both on the nose as well as the palate.  I can see a slight allusion to cognac, as faint aromas from my snifter are of candied apples melted down by smores.  this is a rockin body of brew.  the finish sustains for quite a while, and resembles that of a vintage port.  So, in summary - take a port, an icewine, an xo cognac/armagnac, and your grandmothers molasses; smash them together, and youll have an idea of what this embodies.  2007; rock steady.

Its rich, and full of heat.  luckily, the latter is fairly well masked.  The fact that this is an ale adds to its complexity.  it is first a fruit beer, then it just happens to fall into the ale category, which adds the body to it.  Its tasty, and full of rich raspberry flavor.  The appearance is definitely deceiving to the untrained brewhog.  "blipp"  hit the rating on the head.  kudos.

this is definitely a smokers beer.  the flavors are fairly mellow at first.  However, after a relaxing smoke, the berries are all over the flavor.  Its a pretty cool brew, and i give additional points for originality done well.  but its just kinda too fruity with a lack of balance overall.  nonetheless, its a tasty treat.

12 oz bottle.  pours jet black, but not too thick. typical imp stout pour (creamy, thick, and tinted on the brown side).  the aromas are simple:  chocolate and coffee.  the taste mirrors.  its a tasty stout, but not too complex.  there are defintely hops and malts here, but the hops are simply overshadowed, even for a stout.  its a nice brew, but not the best stout ive ever had.  itd be a good winter brew...go figure.

12 oz bottle.  pours thick with a creamy yet firm head.  The aromas are complex:  heavy roasted malts combined with dark espresso roast;  also, thicker oatmeal like aromas hidden underneath the cacao bean.  thick, also rich in flavor.  brown sugar and molasses as well as baking chocolate and a smooth yet bitter coffee finish.  this is a tasty ale.  as it warms, the alcohol still is well hidden, but the heavier than expected carbonation is revealed.  all in all, its a damn good stout...one i would gladly imbibe on draft.

12 oz bottle purs hazy amber with a frothy, thick lacing head.  aromas show decent hop body and subtle toast.  the taste is subtly hoppy for a pale, showing good body and smooth bittering alpha hops.  subtle fruit and slight pine notes.  This is easy to drink and easy to enjoy, but not as complex as the two hearted ale.  definitely the younger brother, yet to mature.

bomber bottle. pours with a pale green tinge, kinda like cat piss.  huge foamy head dissipates rather quickly.  aroma hits of green apple, strong minerality and stone fruit.  the taste is kind of like a demi sec champagne.  tastes like a dry cider, imagine that.  fruity, strong citrus and acidity, but thank god its not too sweet.  the finish steadily declines leaving a lemon like citrus flavor lingering for a while.  I havent had too many ciders, but I do fancy this one.  It is quite refreshing.

the bomber yields a ripe mahogany pour with minimal head.  The aromas, while rich in bacon and pit bbq, come across a little thin, with accents of salt and bacon fat.  the flavors follow through, but add that smoke flavor from the malts.  and the palate, while think for my personal liking, also is accented by carbonated black fruit.  Its a good beer, but not my fav of smokies.

draft via growler.  The nose is a bit muted, but the aroma tells me its the standard british pub ale.  slightly hoppy, but nothing really jumps out at me.  The finish is fairly short, but leaves a nice flavor on my palate.  I would like to try pairing with food, as it may accentuate the tones and flavors of the brew.  nonetheless, this is really easy to drink and would be a great poker beer.

had this off draft from a tasting recently.  the appearance is definitely porter.  its aroma is very dark and mysterious, a little bit of chocolate and hints of coffee, but also more caramel and roasted malt flavors shining through.  I paired this with a smoked brat, and the two couldnt have been more harmonious unless it was dipped in dark chocolate.  The rye, while noticed, did not add nor detract too much from the overall flavor of the beer.  I personally think this is my favorite brew by Linus and crew.

filled my growler with this today.  this is a sweeter ale, with what i can gather, has some spices present as well as good fruit.  the appearance is a bit of a cloudy one.with aromas reflecting my overall idea of the brew.  its different in comparison to that which Yazoo usually does, but this is why i like them.  the flavor is not overwhelmingly Belgian, but it definitely has its similarities.  the palate is similar to nice chouffe, with similar fruit flavors, malts, and spices going on.  its definitely tasty, and i cant wait to see whats next.  nonetheless, i enjoy this creation.

cloudy amber hue.  nice lacing on the sides of the glass.  aromas are rich and fruity, flavorful and slightly spicy on the finish.  typical ipa flavors.  good easy drinking beer, but 8% can sneak up rather quickly if you arent careful.  just a note.

22 oz bomber.  yeasty grapes, sugar, and runts bananas fill the aromas while burnt orange, dull brown hues fill my glass.  killer lacing, i might add.  cold white grapes, fuzzy peaches, and dark ripe plums dominate the aromas with subtle yeasty sugars and brown sugar spice hit on the back palate.  a certain juiciness hits on the flavor as well, but i cant get to the center of it any deeper than just "juicy fruit," as in, the candy.  palate is smooth, sweet, and hints of saltiness, but nothing overt.  i dig.

12 oz bottle.  aroma - lively fruit, creamy vanilla yeasts; oddly, subtle cranberry and juniper on the nose as well.  very pleasant, very complex.  brown sugar hue.  very approachable.  comforting carbonation.  flavors of rich maple syrup, molasses, brwon sugar, goosenberry jam, blackberry jam, and sugar syrup.  on the palate is moderately heavy, but extremely mellow.  above adequate lacing ensured the pleasant palate in which i do thoroughly enjoy.  the finish is rather smooth, yet subtly heavy.  good brew.  i should age a few more.

750ml taster.  blind tasting.  aromas of sweet malty yeastiness.  the reddish-amber tint gives the ale a hoppy purpose, yet hops are missing from the ale.  my nose tells me this is by far a quad style ale, but not quite done by the masters of belgium.  alcohol hits the backside of the nose.  apricots and oranges pureed in a blender guarantee the sweetness on the nose with just a grace of curacao.  on a personal note - a candle with this aroma could make millions, well, maybe thousands.  syrupy citrus and a dose of Belgian-esque carbonation guarantees this is a crafty brew.  also, there is a grape aspect here, it hits like a muscat.  once again the alcohol hits on the palate...late and towards the back, but it burns where it shouldnt.  however, it still seems quality.  that heat is still relentless.  I dig, but i wish that heat would dissipate.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Sixth Glass Quadrupel

review_blob: bomber.  i just walked into a pine forest and licked every tree in it, then i just sucked the sap and chased it with alcohol and sucked on a hop to top it off.  DAMN!  its a biggie.  avery is beginning to build its name on big ales that pack a bit of a punch.  the 08 version is a whopping 10.54 ABV, with 102 IBUs.  pine, grapefruit rind, honestly - just choking on citrus peel is more like it.  this is big, bitter, and fairly offensive.  dont share with your friends...rather, horde for yourself.  the only thing that is a slight drawback is the price.  id like to cellar this for about 2 yrs and see how it holds up to the elements of aging.  on the scale of ya got it or ya dont  its got it.
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: 12 oz bottle.  the aromas hit like a sugary sweet caramel filled wall. it overwhelms the palate, as im soaking in heavy brown sugar and roasty, toasty malts as well.  the carbonation hits a bit strong for a BW, but is containable for the brew, as its balance comes from the enormous hoppage and maltage emmiting from the subtle oakiness.  as it warms, the alcohol reveals its massiveness.  this is a monster, straight up.   its not the best ale, but its definitely a biggie.  that creamy finish hits, falls off, but lingers for a good minute or two.  You gotta at least try this hellbender.  i dig.

22 oz bomber.  heavy aromas of pine sap wild grasses and over-ripened grapefruit rind; also - orange cream.  the appearance is a toasted orange with a creamy head.  the taste is a slightly bitter ale tasting of light dry hoppage and subtle spice and strong lingering bitterness on the finish.  also, a slightly saltier palate with unsweetened pine bark...its a great concept brew by the guys in athens.
beer_name: Terrapin Side Project Hop Shortage Ale

review_blob: 750ml, pours similar to that of a tawny port, but with influences of a thin brown ale.  the head disappeared quicker than a fat kid in dodgeball, but it still glows in the amber light of my abode.  the aromas carry a grape dominance accented by peppermint, anise, spicy passion fruit, and ripened berries.  it smells very fresh yet rich.  the taste is smooth, as carbonation is minimal, thus allowing the richness and depth of the ale move to the forefront.  it honestly drinks like that of a good syrah.  cola, alcohol, raisins, cherry pits, and maple all show on the palate, giving way to a heated finish.  tis indeed a treat, and should come with two glasses to share with a friend.
beer_name: Gouden Carolus Cuvee Van De Keizer Blauw/Blue

review_blob:
appearance - glowy nut brown, thin head (slight oily tone). aroma - sweet dark chocolate, caramel, nutty undertone, 
syrup.  taste - bitter, chestnuts, hoppy bittersweet, cola, salt, wet rocks.  fairly complex, yet not entirely appetizing.  
nonetheless, still seems pleasant.  palate - salty, bitter lingering finish.  dark 
overripe/borderline rotten fruits hit heavy on the midpalate.  theres an odd funk that i havent tasted in a while on this mouthfeel.  overall, could be better when paired with meatier dishes, even sausage pizza.  though well crafted, by itself its fairly unimpressive. though, the more i drink it, the more it is growing on me.

750ml bottle.  the pour is a burnt orange tinted amber, but with a slight cloudy red tinge. the aroma is peculiar...tart yet juicy fruit, not too hoppy, considering the source.  it has its complexity.  curacao peel, wheat as well.  these aspects are also in the flavor.  the pinot juice adds a nice twist.  good smooth rounded flavor on the palate, the finish hints at oak, and a neutral spice.  flavorful...and crafty.

330ml bottle.  fluffy head and a deep thick maplewood hue. thin, smoky aroma, juicy dark berries, black cherries in the nose as well.  on teh palate, juicy, fruity, and mildly sweet.  the finish is slightly bitter, stone fruit flavors, and dr pepper like carbonation.

12 oz bottle.  glowing dark brown pour, subtle head.  toasted brown sugar, caramel, butterscotch, and even an underlaying chocolate syrup are present in the aroma.   it smells like its a bit syrupy, like molasses or those chewy caramel candies that are wrapped in clear plastic.  the taste shows a heavier ale, with roasted caramel malts, burnt toast, cola like mouthfeel, and a bit of a rough finish.  its actually really easy to drink, and a good ale at that.

12 oz bottle.  pours muddy and dull morning-after pee yellow.  head was bubbly and sprite-like, but disappeared just as quickly as a pop does.  The aroma is barely present, showing muted white peaches and coriander.  The taste is rather accurate for the befitting name.  im just not sure which came first.  Its more of a fruit beer than it is a weisse.  furthermore, unlike any other dfh, wheres the hops?  i was kinda hoping for a hoppy wheater.  all in all, its rather 1D, and perhaps i should retaste it at another time.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: 12 oz bottle.  aroma: sweeter malts, juicy like a sweet plum that has been over-extracted.  even white grapes and passion fruit show up on the nose, as well as a violet and wildflower fragrance.  the appearance yields a thicker brown/earthy hue; head is compiled of millions of tiny bubbles, about avg in size.  the taste is quite unique, even for an eisbock.  its a fruit bomb in the mouth, with elevated acidity; complemented by sweet honey like malts and an alcoholic yet subtly smooth finish with over-ripened berry and bing cherry flavors.  this is quite impressive and the alcohol is masked, though does show itself a bit on the finish.  nonetheless, its quite a clean and scrumptious beer.

12 oz bottle.  heavy bittersweet, toasted slightly oaked aromas.  Bangin on the nose.  taste yielded more of a heavy bittersweet chocolate with an extremely fruity appeal.  mid palate was rather sweet, surprisingly actually, and the finish lingered for quite some time, hitting the bittersweetness over and over again.  minus the price point, i highly recommend the experience, as this is a brew to definitely be shared by many, yet loved by few.
